SummaryOfEvents: On January 1, 2022, the Transport Accident and Incident Investigation Bureau (hereinafter referred to as the Bureau) received a report by phone from representatives of the Maritime Administration of Latvia, that fire broke out on the fishing trawler AUSEKLIS in the Barents Sea. The ship's management and crew acted professionally in accordance with standard shipboard accident/emergency procedures and within 10 minutes the fire was extinguished, but the engine room central electric panel burned, the ship lost propulsion and power.v The master of the ship sent a MAYDAY signal at 01.40 (4 minutes after the fire started), receiving immediate confirmation from the Norwegian Coast Guard. The rescue ship BISON left the port of Batsfjord at 02.53 to provide assistance to the ship AUSEKLIS, reaching it at 22.10. As a result of the rescue operation, the ship was towed to the port of Hammerfest in Norway on January 04, 2022. Crew 23 people, no injuries.

Location: Aguas Interiores, Canal Honda, Tigre, Buenos Aires
SummaryOfEvents: El 30 de diciembre de 2021 a las 18:00 horas la lancha de pasajeros tipo colectivo EL LEÓN VI, navegaba con pasajeros a bordo por el Canal Honda con destino al puerto de Tigre cuando se detectó la presencia de humo en proximidades del motor en la zona media de la embarcación. Posteriormente se observó fuego y las personas a bordo abandonaron la embarcación. Como consecuencia del suceso la embarcación sufrió daños materiales, no se reportaron víctimas fatales ni personas lesionadas.

On the morning of 26 December 2021, at about 0733H, the Singapore registered container vessel, Asiatic Sun (AS) crashed to the no.8A pier, at Taichung Port, Taiwan while berthing under pilotage. The accident did not result in any fatality or injury to personnel and did not result in any pollution. 

The incident vessel suffered structural damage to its bow, the deck area at the bow was distorted downward and cracked at the port side, the reinforced anchor recess was broken, and its shell plate area was distorted. The extent of the damage to the 8A pier was about 10m in length and 4m in width, one rubber fender affixed to the pier’s structure was damaged.

MV Avijan-10 while traveling from  from Dhaka, the capital, to Barguna, about 250km (155 miles) to the south, caught fire off the coast of Jhalokati district on the Sugandha River, toward the end of the journey.
The fire resulted in 39 losses and 70 injuries.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: Collision between Tropic breeze tanker and Utopia 4 super yacht causing the tanker to sink - no loss of life

InitialEvent: fatal accident occurred on cage top of elevator
SummaryOfEvents:
On 17 December 2021, a fatal accident happened on board the Hong Kong registered bulk carrier “Hebei Universe” (the vessel) at Qingdao Chaoliangdao anchorage, China.
At 1735 hours, the duty Oiler (the Oiler) informed the Electrician Officer (the ETO) that the common alarm (the alarm) of the elevator of the vessel (the elevator) activated. The ETO replied that he would check the elevator the next day. At 2130 hours, the duty Engine Trainee (the M/M) discovered some blood came out from the entrance door of the elevator (the entrance door) on the upper deck and immediately reported the situation to the Third Engineer (the 3/E). The 3/E shouted to the entrance door but nobody answered. He then immediately reported the incident to the Chief Engineer (the C/E) and the Master. The engine room crew removed the entrance door on the upper deck and found the ETO was unconscious, lying on the cage top of the elevator bleeding from his nose and mouth. Afterwards, the vessel shifted to the inner anchorage of Qingdao with the permission of the port authority to seek shore medical treatment for the ETO. Unfortunately, the ETO was declared dead after the examination by the shore medical officer in the early morning of 18 December 2021.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: Stranded after dragging anchor, capsized and partially sank whilst moored off Catagbacan, Bohol, Philippines in lat. 09° 52' 32" N, long. 123° 50' 03" E on 16/12/21 in heavy weather from typhoon 'Odette'. Philippine coast guard vessels and MVS 'LCT Poseidon 24' and 'Lite Ferry 88' rescued 25 crew. The master went missing and his body was recovered from the nearby mangroves 2 days later. Wreck abandoned in situ.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On December 14, 2021 m/v Bellona was located in the shipyard “MTG – Dolphin” for repair works.
On December 13, 2021 in one of the ballast tanks hot work took place for cutting some bolts (to dismantle a valve). 
It was done by workers of the subcontractor company ” Galera 07”.
On the morning of December 14, 2021, 2 workers from the company re-entered the tank.
No new hot works were planned for the day. Nevertheless a fire broke out a little later.
After the fire was extinguished, one of the workers was found dead.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: Whilst Curacao Trader was manoeuvring towards the designated anchorage area, off St. Eustatius, a fire broke out in the engine-room, in the vicinity of diesel generator no. 2. The crew members evacuated the engine-room, following which, the fire was extinguished using the vessels fixed firefighting system. While none of the crew members were injured, the vessel sustained significant damages, which took more than three months to repair. The safety investigation concluded that diesel oil sprayed out from a connection on diesel generator no. 2s fuel filter assembly, due to a damaged O-ring, and ignited after coming into contact with hot surfaces.

At about 1530 on 13 September, 2021, a general cargo ship Ryonhwa 3 at anchor, was stranded on the breakwater(30°16.32′N 122°16.947′E) off Xiaochangtu Shan, Zhoushan, China, due to No.14 of Typhoon, resulted in constructive total loss with no loss of life.

SOLASStatus: KARIN HOJ: Unknown/unspecified, SCOT CARRIER: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
The Danish-registered cargo ship Karin Hoej collided with the united Kingdom registered flagged vessel Scot Carrier in the Baltic Sea off the Swedish coast, causing one to overturn. The collision occurred on 13 December 2021  The Scot Carrier was en route to the east coast of Scotland. It is not clear what cargo it was transporting or how many people were on board.
The Scot Carrier is 90m (295ft) long and the Karin Hoej is 55m.

As a result of the collision, the cargo ship Karin Hoj capsized with two crew missing.

Location: Mar Argentino, Rawson Provincia de Chubut
SummaryOfEvents: El 11 de diciembre de 2021 aproximadamente a las 10:551 el B/P Don Tomasso se encontraba en maniobra de pesca a 12 mn de la costa, cuando se dio vuelta campana y se hundió. Como consecuencia del suceso el B/P Sofía B y el B/P Caleta Paula acudieron al auxilio de la tripulación, rescatando esta última embarcación a 6 tripulantes con vida, y el B/P Sofía B el cuerpo sin vida de uno de los marineros.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On the morning of 10 December 2021, the container vessel Moana Chief was preparing to leave the Port of Auckland. The crew had started retrieving the telescopic accommodation ladder when a crew member’s lower leg got trapped between the fixed upper ladder and the moving lower ladder, resulting in serious injury to their leg.
As crew members were retrieving the accommodation ladder, it slipped off the Port platform on which it was resting. The slack side chains allowed the ladder to drop and the weight of the ladder was transferred to the fall wire, which caused the lower ladder to slide upwards. A crew member, who was standing in an area that had previously been identified and designated as a danger area, was seriously injured.
Actions to retrieve the accommodation ladder were not consistent with the procedures documented in the vessel's Safety Management System. Several control measures listed in the risk assessment for deploying and retrieving the accommodation ladder were not implemented. 
It is very likely that the accident could have been prevented, if other crew members standing in the vicinity had intervened and alerted the winch operator to a crew member standing in the designated danger area.

Location: Aguas Interiores, Muelle Heleno Arcángel, Puerto de San Antonio Oeste, Rio Negro
SummaryOfEvents: El 9 de diciembre de 2021 aproximadamente a las 06:451 el buque Sumatra se encontraba amarrado en el muelle “Heleno Arcángel” del puerto de San Antonio Oeste, Río Negro, cuando se originó un incendio que se extendió también a otro buque pesquero, amarrado en andana. Como consecuencia del suceso se reportaron daños en ambos buques y en el muelle. No se registraron personas lesionadas ni daños al medio ambiente.

Sustained a mechanical failure, developed list and sank in the Mediterranean Sea 17 miles NE of Abu Qir, Egypt in lat. 31° 27' 50" N, long. 30° 17' 40" E on 08/12/21 in heavy weather. AHTS 'Maridive 518' and tugs 'Svitzer Rasheed' and 'Svitzer Delta' proceeded to assist. 11 crew rescued and the bodies of 3 remaining crew recovered from the sea and taken ashore. The wreck of the vessel remained at the scene

SummaryOfEvents: At 1445 LT on 4 December 4, 2021, while the vessel was at anchor in Gothenburg Anchorage "A", and the ship was taking bunkers from the barge AMAK SWAN on the port side, the duty watch stander reported smoke coming form the port side forward.  An alarm was sounded and the crew was mustered to fight the fire and crane number 2. The fire teams continued fighting the flames coming from the under the cargo in hold number 1. near the position of the crane number 1. on the Port side. Fire accelerated due to strong winds. Crew managed to keep the fore under control and stopped the spread until external help arrived from Swedish Coast Guard.

On December 2, 2021, at the time of 1820 on Thursday, the ship was heading from the Arab field to the port of Tanajib and collided with a sea buoy, where the wind speed at the time of the accident was high and reached between 20-25 knots per hour, which caused the ship to push towards the sea buoy, as well as confusion The assistant who was driving the ship due to stress and fatigue as a result of working between (6) hours of work and (6) hours of rest for a period of (8) continuous months without a vacation

Took water and sank in the Arabian Sea 15 miles W of Mormugao, India in lat. 15° 24' 00" N, long. 73° 34' 00" E on 02/12/21 in heavy weather. 2 crew rescued from the water by an Indian coast guard Chetak helicopter and another by a patrol vessel. 2 more were rescued by local fishing vessels and 1 body was recovered. The remaining 4 crew were missing. The rescued crew had been in the sea for over 24 hours and were taken to Goa Medical School for medical treatment. Coast guard Dornier 228 aircraft assisted with continuing SAR operations.

SummaryOfEvents: Took water in cargo hold no. 2, developed list to port and subsequently sank in the Sea of Japan, 97 miles NE of Ulleung-do, South Korea in lat. 38° 56' 10" N, long. 131° 09 20" E at 16:31 hours local time (UTC+9) on 01/12/21 in heavy weather. 17 crew abandoned ship to a lifeboat and nearby MV 'Region 87' attended the scene but was unable to rescue the crew due to the adverse weather. All 17 crew were rescued by a South Korean coast guard vessel 12 hours later and taken to Donghae, South Korea. No serious injuries reported. An 18th crew member fell into the sea earlier the same day and went missing. South Korean, North Korean and Japanese coast guard ships and aircraft effected SAR operations.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

On the evening of 26 November 2021, the 18,957 DWT bulk carrier AVIATOR and the 49,999 DWT tanker ATLANTIC GRACE collided in the Gulf of Kutch. AVIATOR was in ballast and was proceeding inbound using the Deep Water route to the anchorage off Kandla. ATLANTIC GRACE was also in ballast and was outbound in the Deep Water route en route Fujairah. AVIATOR was declared a constructive total loss.

At about 1136 on 14 November 2021, Chemical Master departed Haifa, Israel, loaded with a cargo of petrochemicals bound for Amsterdam, The Netherlands, with an ETA at 0200 on 27 November 2021. At around 2330 on 22 November 2021, a fire was detected in the engine-room whilst the vessel was in transit, about 30 nautical miles (nm) off the coast of Portugal. The crew mustered on the poop deck, where it was confirmed that the fourth engineer and the motorman on duty were missing. Quick closing valves (QCVs) were activated, and the engine-room fire dampers were closed. Fire parties were organised, with the first party entering the engine-room at 2345. At 0000, the fire was declared extinguished. The second fire party entered the engine-room at 0003 and located the missing two crew members on the engine-rooms second deck; the motorman was found inside the ECR and the fourth engineer was outside the ECR. Both crew members were carried to the poop deck and given CPR. In the meantime, the Portuguese Coastguard was contacted for medical assistance and both crew members were eventually airlifted. However, the vessel was later informed that both crew members had not survived. Chemical Master was towed to Lisbon, where temporary repairs were carried out to enable the vessel to sail to Poland for permanent repairs. The safety investigation concluded that the cause of the fire may have been related to either accidental spillage, or spray of diesel oil / waste oil onto the incinerator, directly from the deck above whilst the incinerator was either in use or hot after being operated just before the fire.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

On Sunday, November 21, 2021, leaving berth from Calais port, after casting off the hawsers and starting its maneuver, the Cote d'Opale fell on the quay under the effect of the wind. A deckhand on the forecastle had his arm cut off by a fender.

Location: on passage between Rotterdam to New Orleans
SummaryOfEvents: whilst on passage, identified areas of damage to its mooring lines and assigned crew to undertake repairs before load testing. Whilst carrying out the load testing, an ordinary seafarer was fatally injured when the mooring line he was guiding onto the winch drum sprung free from where it had fouled, striking him in the abdomen

In the afternoon of 04 November 2021, the bosun was working aloft with the hydroblaster to de-rust and clean a section of the forepeak tank. Several other crew members were in the forepeak tank to assist with the task. At one point, the bosun fell from a height of about 10 metres, to the bottom of the forepeak tank. He was later evacuated to a hospital. His fall led to disabilities which will prohibit him from pursuing his seafaring career. The safety investigation concluded that due to the restricted visibility in the forepeak tank, the bosun had most probably passed the rotating jet of the hydroblaster gun across the rope, which was connected to his safety harness.

On 29 October 2021, whilst Celebrity Millennium was at anchor at Cabo San Lucas, Mexico, lifeboat / tender no. 11 was lowered and released at sea. While heaving up the davits floating blocks without the boat, the forward fall wire broke, causing the block to fall into the water. No injuries were reported. The safety investigation concluded that the fall wire sustained tensile overload, leading to the parting of the wire.

Whilst PGC Patreas was on a voyage from Mal, Maldives, to Port Blair, India, the duty engineer, and the oiler were conducting a routine waste oil transfer from the sludge tank to the waste oil settling tank. Observing no change in the waste oil settling tank level, the oiler opened the flange of the float guide pipe and moved it aside to investigate. Immediately after, hot waste oil sprayed out from the opening, causing burn injuries to the oiler. Some of the escaping oil spilled on a running diesel generator and ignited. The safety investigation concluded that hot waste oil, which was above the float inside the float guide tube, sprayed out under pressure through the open flange.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: 12 nautical miles to Northern Entrance of Çanakkale Strait / Turkey
SummaryOfEvents:
Çanakkale Strait was closed to maritime traffic on 24th of October 04:30 LT due to heavy fog. BENITAMOU requested pilot for Çanakkale Strait passage. BC VANESSA did not request pilot for Çanakkale Strait passage. At 06:07 LT Panama registered vessel BENITAMOU and Barbados registered vessel BC VANESSA collided at 12 nautical miles to Northern Entrance of Çanakkale Strait/Turkey. 

BENITAMOU sustained a heavy damage and rupture on side shell plating in way of cargo hold number 4. BC VANESSA sustained damage from fore peak. BENITAMOU safely anchored at south of Traffic Seperation Scheme with the assistance of Directorate General of Coastal Safety tugs and later both ships navigated to shipyard for repairs.

On 23 October 2021, the Bahamas flagged bulk carrier Star Peace was on passage, approximately 130’ west southwest of Cape Town, in heavy weather. With access to the open decks restricted, two supernumeraries who were on the sheltered cross deck alleyway noticed the provision crane’s lashings were loose.
Having sent his colleague to the engine room to collect a chain block, the supernumerary fitter climbed on to the crane’s access platform to start securing it. Whilst on the platform, the vessel took a heavy roll, the crane’s remaining lashings parted and the crane travelled at speed to the end of its rail and was lost overboard, along with the supernumerary fitter. He was not recovered.

On 15 October 2021, Kaata was underway in the Baltic Sea, navigating from Rostock, Germany, to Bekkeri, Estonia. The chief officer, together with two able seafarers deck, carried out inspections and maintenance on the vessel's free-fall lifeboat, in preparation for an anticipated port State control inspection at Bekkeri. As part of his inspection, the chief officer stepped onto the free-fall lifeboat. To move around, he had to frequently shift the only securing hook of his safety harness, from one securing point to another. At one point, while carrying out the task, a crew member saw the chief officer slide down the hull of the lifeboat and fall into the water, astern of the vessel. The master sent a distress call on VHF Channel 16, which was immediately answered by the Swedish SAR services. A rescue helicopter was deployed on site, while Kaata also initiated her man-overboard manoeuvre. However, the crew members were unable to locate the chief officer. 20 minutes later, the helicopter arrived on site and engaged in the search operation. Approximately two and a half hours later, the helicopter located the chief officer, recovered him from the water, and transferred him to a shore hospital, where he was pronounced dead. The safety investigation believes that after the chief officer released the hook of his safety harness to secure it to another position, he either lost his footing or slipped on the wet surface of the lifeboats hull, fell into the water, and drowned.

On 13.10.2021 while hoisting the engine mechanism in the engine room the cylinder liner fell down due to cargo lashing strap that was slack and hit two persons. As a result, one person had a fatal injury and one person was injured in the accident.

On October 12, 2021 while the vessel en-route from Whyalla, Australia to Qingdao, China. At about 1826 LT, the vessel position Lat 17-54.8 S Long 114-03.2 E, the Master and Chief Officer (C/O) were discussing administrative matters in the Master’s dayroom, during that moment, the Master and C/O and Master detected a fire from the Master’s bedroom. The C/O proceeded to the bridge to raise the fire alarm, muster crews and initiated the fire team then proceed to the Master cabin to fight the fire with fire extinguishers, fire hoses. At 1920 LT, during fire fighting and rescue, the fire team found and evacuated the unconscious Master in the Chief Engineer’s (C/E) dayroom (adjacent to the Master’s bedroom). When checking visually, the Master had no sign of life, the Oxygen and CPR were performed for about an hour. Casualty’s condition was reported to RCC Australia. RCC Australia advise the vessel to alter course to Barry Island for their assistance and connected with a doctor. CPR by the crew was guided by the shore doctor’s instructions. There was no sign of life after 1 hour of CPR and the condition was confirmed by the shore doctor and RCC Australia responded that vessel was not necessary to deviate her course to Barry Island for assistance.
The C/O checked and confirmed that the fire is completely extinguished, and received advice from CRIM Medico Roma, the Master body was taken to the ship hospital for 24 hours monitoring.
A ship's superintendent fell from a pilot ladder while embarking SUPER RUBY, which was at anchor. The superintendent landed on the launch and was fatally injured.

During the early hours of 12 October 2021, cargo discharging was in progress in cargo hold no. 6 of MV Ludogorets. At one point, the second officer asked the duty AB to check on the forward mooring arrangements. After about 30 minutes, the duty AB had still not returned from the forecastle and calls over portable radio remained unanswered. Ultimately, during a search conducted by the second officer and two other crew members, the duty AB was found at the bottom of the aft access trunk of the cargo hold. Shore medical personnel arrived and confirmed that the duty AB had passed away. The safety investigation confirmed that the duty AB had fallen inside cargo hold no. 6s aft access trunk and landed on the cargo in the cargo hold.

On Saturday 2 October 2021, the sea-river vessel Andre-Michel 1, flying the Maltese flag, was sailing up the Rhne, on ballast, from Torre Annunziata in Italy, bound for Saint-Usage (21) where she was going to load wheat. The maritime crew was made up of 7 Ukrainian seamen. The 68-year-old river pilot, a resident of France, joined the vessel at 7.00 am in Port-Saint-Louis-du-Rhne, where he took over the shiphandling of the vessel. At around 8.15 pm, on the Rhne diversion canal at the level of the town of Donzre (26), the vessel struck the deck of the RN7 bridge at KP 174.5 with her wheelhouse, then that of the railway bridge 150 m further on. The upper part of the wheelhouse was crushed by the impact, it was torn off and tipped backwards and buckled, trapping the river pilot who lost his life. The captain, who was also on the bridge, was slightly injured. After these impacts, the crew managed to stop the vessel a little further on. Frelon, another sea-river vessel, arrived on the scene on 3 October in the middle of the morning. She came alongside the damaged vessel and towed her abreast to a wharf located 2 km upstream. River navigation had been stopped since the accident and resumed shortly before noon. The bridges that were struck were damaged, notably the road bridge, without any major damage. The BEA-TT and the BEAmer draw five safety lessons from this technical investigation and make three safety recommendations.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
On September 25, the vessel “ASTRO TAMOIO” was in dynamic positioning, at the position of Latitude 22°49'41”S and Longitude 043°07'31”W, in the anchorage area 6A of the Guanabara Bay, preparing up to carry out monthly training on the Oil Recovery Operation (“Oil Recovery”). Among the preparations, a safety briefing and the Operation Check List with Service Boat and the DP System were carried out, which involve checks regarding the personnel and material involved.
At around 8:35 am, shortly after the Service Boat started to move to the launch edge, there was an abrupt disconnection of the lifting steel cable from the socket that holds it to the Boat release/attachment device, located on the top of the boat houses, causing, initially, the impact of the Boat with the structure of the vessel "ASTRO TAMOIO" and, then, in the fall of the same in the water capsized, with its three crew members.

The RAMONA sank in the Elbe estuary / Groer Vogelsand after a water inrush caused by loosened planks. The fishing vessel was on a research trip with 2 crew members and 3 scientists on board. All persons were able to save themselves in a life raft and were picked up by the fishing cutter HOFFNUNG. The ships rushed to help, including the rescue cruiser ANNELIESE KRAMER, were unable to prevent the RAMONA from sinking.

At 04:14 LT on 20 Sept. 2021 m/v VERA SU ran aground on Bulgarian coast in Yailata protected area. The ship was en route from port Yuzhniy, Ukraine to Varna, Bulgaria. No injured people. The hull is said to be breached, no risk of pollution of environment.

M/V VERA SU has departed from Pivdennyi, Ukraine to Varna, Bulgaria on 18.09.2021 20.05lt with 2837.201MT urea prilled in bulk as per cargo manifest and 26.641MT ballast, 28.70MT diesel Oil, 3.80MT lube oil as per draft survey report. 9 crew member including master were on board according to the crew list.
     On 19.09.2021 at 23.50lt, 2nd D/O was taken over the watch from the master. The course altered to 247° at 01.55lt on GPS pos 43° 32’ 05” N - 028° 53’ 16” E. At this point it must be highlighted that 2nd D/O was alone on bridge during watch, BNWAS is not operational (Off) and the approved passage plan was not in use, the plan has changed verbally between master and officers. 2nd D/O felt asleep due to felt tired while waiting next WP to alter course to Varna separation scheme.
   The vessel grounding with full ahead around 7.8kts from forward part on 20.09.2021 at 04.13lt on Yailata rocky area, Bulgaria. (Gps position 43° 25.92’ N - 028° 32.34’ E) At that time weather condition recorded as wind direction NW, wind force 3, visibility good (5-6) and sea condition was moderate.
    After grounding, Master together with C/O came to bridge (on about 04.15lt), in order to check what happened and to evaluate overall vessel condition, then Master, as per company SMS Chap. 12 section 12.1.4.2.1 procedures, officially informed local authorities (Varna VTS, Varna MRCC) and the company about the incident. Also deck crew members were instructed to check ballast tanks by taken soundings, and visual inspection conducted around ship. Master tried to refloat the ship by using main engine ahead and astern, but without success then order to stop M/E, steering gear was placed in midship position. At this point it must be highlighted that C/O was late to his watch on bridge. There were no crew fatalities, oil spill nor any other kind of pollution reported.

Location: Aguas Interiores, Tigre, Primera Sección de Islas del Delta, Arroyo Caraguatá, Canal Gobernador Aria
SummaryOfEvents: El 16 de septiembre de 2021 la lancha de pasajeros tipo colectivo L/M “RIO CARABELAS”, bandera argentina, amarró a muelle sobre el arroyo Caraguata, próximo a la intersección con el Canal Gobernador Arias. A las 19:50 horas, durante el alistamiento de la lancha previo a la zarpada, se produjo un incendio a bordo. Como consecuencia del suceso se ocasionaron daños materiales serios en la embarcación.

SOLASStatus: LISA AUERBACH: Unknown/unspecified, MY AN 1: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
The M.V. Lisa Auerbach arrived at Vung Tau, Vietnam anchorage on September 13, 2021 at 1224 LT. The master informed the Investigator that the Pilot boarding was scheduled for  September 14, 2021 at 0400 LT. The Vung Tau VTS confirmed pilot boarding time was 0400LT on September 14, 2021 at buoy No. 5. 
At 0212LT on September 14, 2021, the M.V. Lisa Auerbach heaved up the Starboard anchor, and proceeded to pick up the pilot, while the Lisa Auerbach was approaching buoy No.5, the Bosun at the forward station, reported an object ahead without any lights. The Bosun further stated the distance to the object was closing. The speed of the Lisa Auerbach was 11.1 kts.  The object was later found to be the anchored vessel M.V. My An 1. The M.V. Lisa Auerbach collided with the M.V. MV My An 1 on her Starboard side at 0224 LT on 14 September 2021 and the M.V. My An 1 sank. The master of the  Lisa Auerbach immediately reported to Vung Tau VTS and port control  the collision and commenced Search and Rescue (SAR) operations. A total of 13 crewmembers and 4 passengers were successfully rescued from the M.V. My An 1.

Location: Strait of Sicily 37 miles E of Pantelleria
SummaryOfEvents: Caught fire in the engine room and disabled whilst underway in the strait of Sicily 37 miles E of Pantelleria. Blaze extinguished by crew. Extent of damage was unknown. Two crew sustained injuries, one of whom was airlifted ashore by helicopter for medical attention. The 2 crew subsequently died. Nearby mv ASL Grace attended the scene. Subsequently taken in tow by AHTS Carlo Magno later the same evening to Augusta, Italy for inspection and repairs.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: Two-seafarers deceased, due to hit by a seawave of abnormal height, which resulted in their deaths, on board the ship mts ARAFURA ( IMO No; 9728708) while the ship was enroute to Long Beach from Brazil.

During the unloading operation of Panama registered bulk carrier ESRA C, at 08th of September 2021 around 14:00 LT (GMT+3) laden block cargo fell over a Turkish citizen shore worker in cargo hold number 4. Unfortunately, after a while the shore worker passed away.

On September 08, 2021, in the early morning, L'AMI SINCERE leaves the port of Grandcamp-Maisy, for fishing. A person, without qualification or professional certificate, is embarked in place of an absent sailor. During a trap launching manouver, this person was swept overboard. Attempts to rescue the man overboard failed, and the victim was pronounced dead by drowning.

On September 02, 2021 about 1320 LT, while the vessel completed her cargo loading operation at Owendo anchorage, Gabon, position Lat 00-17.0 N Long 009-25.8 E, the Able Seafarer (AB) who just had completed his 0800~1200 duty was assigned to secure the cargo crane No.2 and secure the electrical cable for No.1 crane/grab by Bosun at about 1250 LT with Cadet’s assistance. After lowering the crane jib to the secure position of crane No.2 the victim AB climbed down from crane No.2 emergency access of the crane cabin to the crane middle platform in order to proceed to secure the electrical cable for No.1 cargo crane. While the victim AB climbed down, he fell onto the cross deck After part of the cargo hold No.1. The victim AB was found lying head down against the hydraulic pipes, unconscious with a weak pulse and bleeding from his left ear. The Master contacted the local agent for medical assistance and administered the oxygen. The victim AB was lowered to the boat which was carrying out the draft survey with Chief Officer had sent the injured AB to shore hospital accompanied by 2nd.Officer and another AB. At  1440 LT, the shore doctor pronounced the injured AB deceased from his injuries.

Location: South Atlantic Ocean, 800 miles of Uruguay
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship sustained explosion in engine room, caught fire and lost power in the South Atlantic Ocean, 800 miles E of Punta Del Este, Uruguay at 1700 hours LT (UTC-3) on 1 Spetember 2021. 

A crew member died in the incident. The Uruguayan Navy salvage vessel ROU 'MALDONALDO' proceeded to the scene to assist. Owners hired AHTS 'BG WARRIOR' on 4 September 2021 to effected tow to an achorage off Montevideo, Uruguay arriving on 18 September 2021 for inspection. The ship was berthed alongside Montevideo on 23 September 2021 for repairs.

At about 2235 on 30 August 2021, the chief officer (C/O) of the Isle of Man
registered general cargo vessel Teal Bay was fatally injured when he was struck
on the head by a tensioned mooring line that sprang out of an open roller fairlead.
Teal Bay was loading grain when moored alongside an anchored bulk carrier. The
mooring line was being used to pull Teal Bay forward and it sprang free when its
lead angle became too great for the open fairlead to restrain it.

On August 29, 2021 at about 1120 LT, the vessel at South of Bozcaada Anchorage, Turkey, Bearing and distance from Camlik Point 219 degrees and 1.86 Nautical Miles, Lat39 48.4 N Long 025 57.3 E, during the Demucking of cargo tanks in preparation for proceeding to drydock. The company Superintendent who had been overseeing the vessel for shipyard was inspecting the No.3 Pt COT tanks de-mucking had been found at the bottom of the tank by Cadet. The alarm was raised, the Chief Officer (C/O) and the Chief Engineer (C/E) entered the tank after verifying that the atmosphere in the space was tested and found safe to enter. They found the company Superintendent severe injury to his head, lying face down and without any sign of life.

After refuelling a recreational motorboat exploded and a major fire started. Of the three people on board a woman was severely burned, her husband and daughter were lightly burned, another person on the quay was shocked. Faced with the difficulty extinguishing the fire, the motorboat was towed outside the port and sunk.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: On 23-8-2021 whilst at sea returning from fishing one crew member was seen on the kitchen deck with spasms due to electrocution. SAR was requested and the crew provided life support. The injured crew member was taken to hospital where he passed away two days later.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
On August 25, 2021 at about 1730 LT, the vessel departed from Bejaia, Algeria to Cartagena / Spain to load the cargo, when the vessel position Lat 35-25.8 N Long 002-53.4 E, the Master, Bosun, and 2 Able Seafarers (ABs) were collapsed inside the cargo tank No.4 Stb and No. 4 Pt where the crews had been carrying out washing, mopping tank cleaning operation of previous cargo ““crude degummed soybean oil”. 
During the afternoon, the AB1 who was on duty at the main deck at the No.4 Pt tank manhole saw the Bosun and AB2 lying down at the bottom of the tank. The Master and Chief Officer (C/O) were notified immediately as they proceeded to the scene.  When they were at the scene, noted that the AB1 was also lying down at the bottom of the tank. The Master immediately entered the tank without PPE. The Master collapsed as soon as he reached the tank bottom. The rescue team had been activated immediately and lifted the victims from the tank. The Shore Medical advice and helicopter assistance were requested. The Helicopter rescue team arrived at the vessel and declared that the Master, Bosun, and AB2 were deceased. The AB1 was evacuated to the nearest shore hospital.

At noon on 17 August 2021, the work vessel SEAWORKER ran aground at Bredbden south of Karlskrona. Two people were on board, the master and a deckhand. They had been on their way from Utklippan back to Karlskrona. Automatic steering was used to keep the course. Some time into the trip, the master became very tired and felt that he needed to rest. He then left the conning of the ship to the deckhand, who, however, remained in the passenger seat. The deckhand lacked nautical competence, but had been on trips to Utklippan before. Just before Bredbden, the deckhand noticed that they were about to run aground. There was no time to make any corrective measures and the ship hit the ground at a speed of about 15 knots. The sea rescue operation was hampered by the fact that the area around the ship was shallow and no other ships could go near SEAWORKER. Both crew members were rescued by being lifted into a sea rescue helicopter, less than an hour after the grounding. The crew of SEAWORKER escaped with bruises and abrasions. The damage to the SEAWORKER, however, was extensive and the ship was later scrapped. At the time, there was a weak southwesterly wind and meter-high swells. The visibility was very good. The grounding was caused by a lack of attention to lookout and navigation. Due to fatigue, the master left the operation of the ship to the deckhand, who had no formal nautical training. He also did not have proper conditions to be able to perform the task as he remained in the passenger seat in the wheelhouse. An underlying reason may be that the master was ill the previous week and probably misjudged his general condition, this in turn may have influenced the decision to let the deckhand handle the ship from the passenger seat.

On August 16, 2021 at about 1505 LT, while en route from Jeddah, Saudi Ariba to Tanger Med, Morocco loaded with General Cargo in Containers, at the Mediterranean Sea, position Lat 33-47 N Long 024-43 E, the Electrician (E/O) who was working at main cooling seawater pump No.2 motor located at engine room bottom platform had an electric shock when he was connecting winding heater cables. The Wiper 1 who was assigned to work together with E/O had noticed the situation had pulled the electric cables from E/O’s hand and tried to revive him. Wiper 1 ran and called for help to C/E and 2/E who were in Engine Room(E/R), they both went down, raised the alarm, and started given CPR.
The E/O was found unconscious with no external injury, CPR was given continuously. The Master contacted RCC Alexandria but not responded, contacted MEDICO ISRAEL by phone and informed the situation, the distance from the nearest land, and requested a medical evacuation. MEDICO ISRAEL relayed the message to RCC GREECE. 
The RCC GREECE responded to send their helicopter evacuation and instructed the vessel to the rendezvous point at KRITI ISLAND, GREECE. On August 16, 2048 LT, the rescue helicopter airlifted the injured E/O to shore hospital. Unfortunately, the E/O was declared Dead on Arrival by the hospital.

On Thursday, August 12, 2021 at 8:00 p.m. approximately, the fishing boat "NIÑA AMYLU" was sailing high near the point of "Subida Alta", two of the people on board noticed smoke was coming out from engines room, when they entered the engine room there was fire, at that moment they gave the alert to the rest of the crew and proceeded to release other small boats tied up to the vessel stern, in matters of minutes the ship was filled with smoke and the crew trying to save itself from the flamesafter that the engine room make an explosion.
There were 19 crew members on the ship, two of them without authorization, of which 18 were rescued by another fishing boat named Merlina who gave alert the authorities. One crew member was found death 4 days later.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: The general cargo vessel Arklow Clan, berthed alongside at the Port of Aberdeen, Scotland, United Kingdom (UK) during the afternoon of 11 August 2021, in ballast condition, and scheduled to commence loading a cargo of scrap metal in bulk the following morning. At around 17.49 hours (hrs), three crewmembers commenced lowering the walkway handrails in preparation for loading operations. Whilst lowering the handrails, the Second Officer lost his footing, falling around 3.6 metres (m) from the walkway to the quay below. As a result of the impact the Second Officer sustained serious injuries to both his legs, necessitating an extensive period of hospitalisation, multiple surgeries, and rehabilitation.

On August 9, 2021, at about 1838 LT, the Chief Officer(C/O) who climbed down the Port side combination ladder to service boat had been pinched by the launch boat and fell into the sea at position Lat 26-47.6 S Long 153-14.7 E. The Man Over Board C/O was recovered by Launch boat and given CPR. The launch boat turned back ashore with C/O for about 40 minutes to a local hospital, Unfortunately, after 3 hours of emergency medical treatment, the C/O was pronounced deceased at 2130 LT on 9th.August 2021. The weather was recorded as Overcast Sky, Visibility- Good, Sea-Moderate, Swell- Rough with Fresh Breeze.

At approximately 18.05 hours (hrs) on 5 August 2021, when en route to Passage East, Co. Waterford the Master of the vessel Frazer Tintern detected a strong smell of diesel fuel. At that point, a crewmember called him to say that he could also get a strong smell of diesel and was going to investigate. When the crewmember got to the mesh door at the number one (No.1) engine compartment he was met with black smoke and flames. The crewmember notified the Master straight away that they had a fire onboard. The Master immediately shut down the No.1 engine and turned off the engine room fans. Two crewmembers then activated two portable fire extinguishers and rigged fire hoses to provide boundary cooling. The vessel continued to the Passage East slipway to get passengers off as quickly and safely as possible. As a precaution all passengers were summoned to the muster station and issued with lifejackets. On the way to the Passage East slipway the fire was brought under control. On arrival at Passage East all passengers and vehicles were disembarked in a safe manner. The vessel was then secured, and the remaining engines shut down. When the smoke dispersed fully the crew investigated the engine room to confirm the fire had been extinguished.

On Wednesday August 04, 2021 aboard the river fast boat named "WAYRA" with two crew members and 12 passengers, at approximately 9:00 a.m. near the Añangu commune in the Napo River. The incident occurred because of the motorist of the boat was not able to see a piece of wood in the river because of the fast speed of the boat. He could not perform the appropriate maneuver, the wood hit the engines and as a result of that it loses the control of the unit causing the turn and capsizing of the vessel, 06 people on board died because of the closed structure of the vessel and the river current.

Location: Mar Argentino, Zona Económica Exclusiva. San Clemente del Tuyu.
SummaryOfEvents: El 31 de julio de 2021, aproximadamente a las 21:00 horas, el buque pesquero Siempre San Salvador, bandera argentina, se hundió mientras realizaba faenas de pesca aproximadamente a 70 millas náuticas al este de la localidad de San Clemente del Tuyu, provincia de Buenos Aires. Las condiciones meteorológicas eran favorables para la navegación. El B/P El Faro rescató a toda la tripulación.

Location: Río de la Plata. Km 145, Canal Punta Indio
SummaryOfEvents: El día 29 de julio de 2021 el buque tanque gasero Hoegh Esperanza, bandera noruega, en navegación de entrada por el Río de la Plata, quedó varado en el veril verde del Kilómetro 145 del Canal Punta Indio (ex Par 21) obstruyendo parcialmente la navegación.

Capsized and sank whilst underway in the Arabian sea 200 miles SW of Dwarka, India in lat. 21° 55' 09" N, long. 65° 50' 21" E on 29/07/21 in heavy weather. The 18 crew members abandoned ship into the water. A Pakistan navy aircraft flew over the scene and air dropped life rafts to assist the crew. 5 crew were rescued by passing MT 'Elan Vital', 5 by MT 'Desh Abhimaan' and 5 by an unknown vessel. The 15 survivors were transferred to the Pakistan navy frigate 'Aslat' and Pakistan maritime security patrol vessel 'Kashmir' and taken to Karachi, Pakistan. No serious injuries reported. SAR operations effected for 3 missing crew.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: South China Sea, 18 miles SE of Hui Dong, China
SummaryOfEvents: The ship developed list, capsized and sank in the South China Sea, 18 miles SE of Gangkou Zhen, Hui Dong, China in LAT. 22 18'36"N, LONG. 115 01'25"E at 1057 hours LT (UTC+8) on 25 July 2021. The incident was reportedly due to a leg punch through. Several crew fell overboard, 61 crew were evetually rescued by nearby vessels and 4 went missing. Local authorities dispatched rescue vessels and helicopters to conduct SAR operations. Divers searched the sunken wreck but were unable to locate the missing crew. No pollution was reported.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: Mar Argentino, Zona contigua. ZEEA (Zona Económica Exclusiva)
SummaryOfEvents: El 23 de julio de 2021 a las 1840 horas un auxiliar de máquinas sufrió un shock eléctrico mientras se encontraba realizando tareas en su puesto de trabajo.

The ship sustained main engine failure, took water and subsequently sank in the Gulf of Khambhat 8 miles W of Umargam, India in lat. 20° 11' 28" N, long. 72° 37' 05" E on 21/07/21 in heavy weather. The engine failure was reported due to fuel contamination. Anchored to await assistance. MV 'Hermeez' attended the scene and rescued all 12 crew. The vessel was left adrift and subsequently sank further NE the following day. Wreck to be removed from Oct 2022.
Deck Cadet fell approximately 8.5 m from the free fall lifeboat davit platform to the Poop Deck. He died several days later as a result of the injuries he received.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: On the journey from Juist to Norddeich, the outboard engine of the boat failed. The taxi boat, which had seven passengers on board, was towed safely to Norddeich harbour by another taxi boat.

Location: Mile 93.5 on the lower Mississippi near New Orleans Louisiana , USA
SummaryOfEvents:
The Liberia Registered bulk carrier JALMA TOPIC was sailing in ballast upriver on the Lower Mississippi River, when it lost steering and struck a barge with an office accommodation structure on the river bank at mile 93.5 near New Orleans, Louisiana. None of the 3 persons on the office barge, or 20 persons (19 crew and a pilot) on the JALMA TOPIC were injured. The office barge and moorings sustained serious damage. The bow of the JALMA TOPIC was also damaged. There was no pollution. 

After the incident, a pilot boarded the vessel and requested tug assistance to secure the vessel.  

On July 13 and 14, 2021, a Lloyds Surveyor attended the JALMA Topic and structural repairs were identified. 

On July 15 2021, a technician from Mackay Marine attended the JALMA TOPIC, and found a defective relay contact, for the Port feedback operation signal on steering pump No1. It was promptly renewed by vessel’s spare and the system tested satisfactory. As per preventive action the relays contact for the Steering Gear No2 were renewed accordingly. 

On July 26, 2021 repairs were completed to the satisfaction of the attending surveyor, the vessel operator, and the US Coast Guard.

AGGERSE was enroute from the fishing ground to the port of Hirtshals when the ship suddenly listed to port and lost stability. The crew decided to resue themselves by means of the liferaft. Hours later the ship foundered.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On July 13, 2021 at 03:15 the trawler MANGA REVA sets sail from Guilvinec to go to the langoustine fishing area located 14 miles from the port. Twenty minutes later, the trawler L'OCARINA sets sail in turn to go to the same fishing grounds. At 05:40, the MANGA REVA arrived in the area and changed course to launch its fishing gear, the crew was on the working deck to carry out this maneuver. The skipper takes an overview of the situation on the water before going down to join them. He sees a ship heading towards him, he is less than a mile away, he believes that ship has seen him and is going to maneuver. He descends at the controls of the winch. The sailors are at their posts near the poop on each side. The ship is on autopilot, no one keeps watch on the bridge. The working deck is a covered deck, so there is no side visibility. The second ship, L'OCARINA is on its way. The skipper and a seaman are resting at the crew station. The other seaman, who is on watch, leaves him momentarily to go down on deck. This ship is therefore also left without watch for a few minutes. The road of L'OCARINA then crosses the road of MANGA REVA which in the meantime has changed course. The OCARINA approached the MANGA REVA on her aft starboard side. The MANGA REVA fills with water and sinks. The crew members are all picked up by another ship present in the area.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

Location: Family Win Dry dock, Hlaingtharyar Township, Yangon, Myanmar
SummaryOfEvents:
On the day of 10-Jul-2021, 0745 hrs local time, while cargo vessel “MV SHWE THU WAN” (Official Number 6205A) was docked and carrying out repair for hull plates at Family Win Dry dock, fire started to break out in her no.5 port side cargo hold and then fire spread to engine room.
Due to the presence of combustible materials in the engine room, fire was developed up to the wheel house through the accommodation and finally it was extinguished in 0835 hrs local time by the firefighting of ship crew, dock staff and the downtown fire brigade.

After lifting the fishing nets, debris was removed from the net. A piece of wood was entangled in the net. When removing the piece of wood a finger got stuck in the net. When trying to pull the net off the finger, the top of the finger was cut off . The victim was wearing gloves.

Location: Puerto Madryn, Muelle Almirante Storni, Provincia de Chubut
SummaryOfEvents: El día 05 de Julio de 2021 a las 03:26 horas el B/P “Florida Blanca IV” colisiono contra el muelle Almirante Storni. Como consecuencia del suceso se ocasionaron daños materiales en el buque y en el muelle.
When following a towing train "SARMAT" - Vessel " BOURBON BISON"(towed object) in the Atlantic Ocean the towed object sank at a depth of about 60 m.
Ship's overhead provision crane failed and fell to the deck while garbage was being discharged. One seafarer was fatally injured and another was seriously injured.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
The ship sank in the Bali strait whilst approaching Gilimanuk, Bali, Indonesia, in LAT. 08 10' 26" S, LONG. 114 25' 42" E at 19:20 hours LT (UTC+8) on 29 June 2021.
Local authorities effected SAR operations. 53 persons were rescued, and 7 people were dead. No pollution was reported.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On 28 June 2021, the crew on board MV Ketter were opening her hatch covers in preparation of discharging a cargo of marble chips in bulk, at the port of Antwerp. The hatch covers were being opened by the chief mate who was operating the gantry crane with the master and an able-bodied seafarer (AB) assisting the chief mate with the positioning of the gantry hooks and hatch covers. All three persons were in radio contact and the opening of the five aft hatch covers went smoothly. During the positioning of the final forward hatch cover, the (AB) became momentarily trapped between the forward bulwark and the gantry crane resulting to serious crush injuries to his chest.

On June 25, 2021, while en- route from Colombo, Sri Lanka to Singapore, the weather was recorded as a partly cloudy sky, wind- Moderate to Fresh, Sea- Moderate to Rough with good visibility. At about 0125 LT, approximate position Lat 05 53.0 N Long 088 37.0 E, the 2nd. Officer (2/O) who was a Navigation Officer on Watch (NOOW) had noticed the fire broke out in the Engine and activated the fire alarm. The crews mustered and observed that Junior Engineer(J/E) was found to be missing. At 0139 LT, the Fire & Rescue team attempted to enter ER to search had failed due to the intense heat, thick smoke, and flames. At 0155 LT, the Master ordered to release the CO2 to ER.
On June 26, 2021 about 1206 LT, after ER had been cooling down, the Fire & Rescue Team found the J/E body near the chemical store between platform No. 2 and No.3 Starboard side (STB) in the ER. The vessel engaged the tug to tow to Singapore. On June 27, 2021 about 1730 the deceased J/E body had been transferred to MSC DEILA (9461415). On July 06, 2021 at 1106, the vessel arrived in Singapore for repairs.

On 21 June 2021, whilst Intrepid was outside Brazilian territorial waters, a riding team boarded the vessel to assist in the cargo holds cleaning, in preparation for the next cargo. On 24 June, the riding team was washing cargo hold no. 5. Shortly after 0700, the riding team leader reported to the master that one of his team members had fallen into the empty cargo hold. The crew members proceeded to the area. However, soon after, the chief officer reported that neither a pulse nor any signs of breathing could be detected on the shore person. The fatally injured shore persons centre of gravity had most likely shifted above and inboard of the hatch coaming, causing him to fall into the cargo hold.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: On the 22nd June 2021 the 9,978 gross tons container Ship “CFS WIND” moored alongside the number 3 berth Gordon Cay pier Kingston Freeport Terminal Limited and commenced cargo operations shortly thereafter.  Whilst alongside the Kingston freeport Terminal (KFTL) and conducting cargo operations, a twenty-foot container secured atop cargo bay number five was damaged due to over pressurizing of its cargo that was contained in a flexible storage tank (Flexi-bags).  The contents of the storage tank contaminated the cargo holds number two (2) and three (3), catwalks, the berth, and other containers onboard within the vicinity.  Although the deck scuppers were in position (in preparation for the bunkering exercise to commence once the vessels docked), of the 25 tons of cargo discharged, some of the liquid spilt over the ships side resulting in an approximately two (2) tons of pollutant spilt overboard.

The ship was in collision with a fishing boaat whilst berthing at Bima, Nusa Tenggara Barat, Indonesia at 1900 hours LT (UTC+8) on 20 June 2021. No injuries, damamge or pollution was reported on this ship, the ship was subsequently berthed for inspection. The collided fishing boat broke into two and sank, 1 one of her crew members died and the other one was critically injured and was taken to hospital for medical attention.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
The ship broke in two and sank in the Arabian sea 95 miles SW of al Duqm, Oman, in LAT 18 20' 00" N long. 057 20' 00" E at 0520 hours LT (utc+4) on 20 June 2021 in heavy weather.
All crew abandoned the ship into a life raft or the water. MV 'Rudolf', Yacht 'PLVS Vltra' and JSDF MCMV 'URAGA' attended the scene. 10 crew were rescued by 'PLVS Vltra' and 9 by 'Rudolf'. No serious injuries were reported. An oil slick and floating debris were observed in the area.

On Friday, June 18, 2021, the fishing vessel SEXTANT ends a scallop fishing trip. Around 09:30, it is located in the north-west of the island of Alderney and the crew is busy arranging the equipment for the return to the port of Cherbourg. Suddenly, one of the poles went back to sea, dragging one of the sailors and injuring another. Despite the efforts of the crew, the sailor overboard could not be recovered. He will be airlifted and declared deceased by drowning.

Location: Yavuz Sultan Selim Bridge/Northern exit of Strait of İstanbul/Turkey
SummaryOfEvents: While AS ROSALIA was making its’ South-North passage of Strait of İstanbul, a collision happened between AS ROSALIA and BİRİNCİOĞLU fishing vessel at 15:12 on 17th of June 2021 around Yavuz Sultan Selim Bridge. BİRİNCİOĞLU fishing vessel flooded because of collision and became semi-submerged. One person on the BİRİNCİOĞLU fishing vessel was rescued but two persons were taken as unconscious and transferred to the ambulance but unfortunately both died.

Location: the waters adjacent to Geojedo Island
SummaryOfEvents: The LNG Tanker, HYUNDAI TECHNOPIA, departed from shipyard at 15:06 on 16th June 2021. At 16:52 on the same day when the AB, OS(A) and OS(B) were facing one another and lifting the toolbox on the electric cable way atop cargo tanks, OS(B) lost his balance and fell towards the chain railings, plunging about 18 meters onto the upper deck. OS(B) had serious injury and eventually died after moved to a hospital.

Able seaman Mohamed Shaffie (CDC C032260) was under medication for Gastritis since 19 April 2021. Around 2345 hrs. lt on 13th June 2021 reported severe pain in upper abdomen, vomiting and unable to sleeping after dinner. The 2nd Officer treated him with the help of radio medical advice and given him a bed rest. 0754 hrs. On 16th morning severe pain all over the body and suddenly became unconscious around 0815 hrs. Cleared the mouth and airway, pulse, heartbeat, temperature, continued WITH CPR. Vessel was around 177 miles off coast of Cocos Island and reported to all respective authorities including MRCC Australia. Contacted doctor from MRCC over the satellite phone and update the condition. Vessel divert to Cocos island as per DPA advice and on the way to the nearest land of Cocos island, the doctor from MRCC examined him and confirm the patient is deceased.

Indian coast guard aircraft attended the scene. 10,000 litres of heavy fuel oil leaked into the water. They continued on the voyage to Haldia, India, for inspection and repairs.
Crew member jump overboard while the vessel was at sea.

Location: South Atlantic Ocean, about 14NM off Brazil
InitialEvent: Man Overboard while performing deck work sitting on a 'A' frame portable ladder
SummaryOfEvents:
On 10 June 2021, the SRS gas carrier, MT Epic Boracay, was transiting in the South Atlantic Ocean, bound for a Brazilian port. At about 0800H (local time), after handing over the navigational watch to the Third Officer, the Chief Officer tasked two able-seafarer deck (ASD) to carry out painting work for the undersides of two separate stairway landings from the boat-deck.

After the ASDs collected the required tools, they began the painting work using telescopic rods connected to roller-brushes. About an hour into the painting work, one of the ASDs (ASD-1) saw the other ASD (ASD-3) carrying a portable A-frame ladder to the boat-deck. Shortly after, the ASD-3 was seen sitting on top of the ladder carrying out the painting and then losing his balance when the ladder tilted, while EB was altering course. The ASD-3 and the ladder fell overboard. 

A man-overboard procedure was carried out and with the assistance of a nearby fishing vessel, the motionless body of ASD-3 was recovered on board. Attempts to resuscitate the ASD-3 were unsuccessful.

On the early afternoon of 5 June 2021, fire caught the engine room of the fishing vessel Lokarda while she was trawling within the territorial waters of Republic of Croatia (about 15,4 NM south of the island of irje). Crew members immediately noticed the fire and started extinguishing it. They used all available firefighting equipment and still weren't able to extinguish the fire, so the fire spread to other parts of the vessel and forced crew members to abandon the vessel. Vessels of the marine police, Harbormasters offices Split and ibenik and other nearby vessels were sent to the site. Crew members were rescued by the fishing vessel Strelica, which first arrived. Crew members then embarked the boat of the Harbormasters office Split - Branch in Milna and sailed towards the Port of Trogir for medical examination. Other vessels at the site could not extinguish the fire so the firefighting vessels were sent towards the fishing vessel Lokarda. One firefighting vessel arrived at the site and started extinguishing the fire, however fishing vessel Lokarda foundered at 21:05 local time (UTC + 2) to a depth of about 180 meters.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
- The Master completed the toolbox meeting with the C/O at 09:50lt. The C/O at 13:45 descended in cargo hold no.7 by using the Australian ladder.
- After a while 13:50, the AB was looking for C/O and observed that entrance covers of cargo hold no.7 was open and went down from the Australian ladder to check if C/O needs any assistance and he saw him next to the vertical ladder laying on the tank top and moaning, with his head bleeding all crew alerted and proceeded to Cargo Hold no.7 following the Company's procedures for serious injury/accident. They provided first aid, medical oxygen, blankets etc. It was observed that the C/O was heavily injured at back side of his head. The breathing signs were reducing and after several trials and continuous oxygen and breathing assistance it was verified that the heart stopped with no sign of breathing and no activity on eyes. After taking permission from AMSA doctor the crew recovered the body on deck and transferred to the hospital

On June 3rd 2021, Mv CENTRAL PARK loaded a cargo of sulphuric acid at the port of Antwerp. Around 0920, an AB accompanied the BV surveyor towards the manifold on board to take samples of a filled cargotank. Meanwhile, the filling of another cargotank had just finished. During purging of the charging line, a leakage occured at a packing seal at 10m distance from the AB and a mist of sulphuric acid was blown towards the AB. The AB was not wearing any specific PPE, as he was not taking any samples and he was keping sufficient distance from the manifold where the surveyor was busy. The AB got chemical burns over his face and body and was transported to a hospital nearby.

At 1620 hours on 2 June 2021, a fire broke out on board Panama registered general cargo vessel “Affluent Ocean” (the vessel) causing its structural damage while the vessel was anchoring at Kellett Anchorage No.3, Hong Kong, for loading scrap metal in bulk. The fire was extinguished at about 0820 hours on 3 June 2021. Fortunately, there were no casualties and oil pollution.

The ship struck a submerged wreck, took water and subsequently sank in the Gulf of Suez 4 miles SE of Ras Ghareb, Egypt, in LAT. 28 19' 00" N, LONG. 033 07' 55" E late pm on 1 June 2021.
It sustained a hole in the hull's starboard side, and the ship sank within 10 minutes. 4 tugs were dispatched to the scene, and 11 crew were rescued. The captain was killed, and a crew member was reported missing during the incident. No pollution was reported. The body of the missing crew member was later recovered from the submerged wreck.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: Kvistgaard Jrn och Metall AB was a scrap metal recycling company that had a facility in Landskrona harbour. On the morning of 31 May 2021, a scrap shipment was being loaded on the vessel SALAR. The cargo was declared as metal waste and was to be exported to Latvia on behalf of the recycling company. Shortly before 2 p.m. smoke developed in the cargo hold. The crane operator assumed that it was a powder fire extinguisher that broke and continued loading. After a short while the smoke development increased, the loading was stopped and the port staff called 112. Resources from the Landskrona Fire Service arrived at the scene shortly after the alarm and The Coast Guard assisted in the extinguishing work. The development of smoke was extensive which resulted in an evacuation of a shipyard in the wind direction. Also, a so-called Important Announcement to the Public signal was sent out. It took almost twelve hours to extinguish the fire. The fire caused minor damage to the vessel. The metal waste was mixed with different types of combustible material such as foam plastic, car tires and wood. Small amounts of flammable liquid were also found in the waste. The probable cause of fire was sparks or frictional heat generated during loading that ignited flammable liquid or other flammable material. The inspections of the waste were insufficient and waste with hazardous properties was therefore not removed. The risks of handling metal waste mixed with combustible material had also not been properly addressed.

SummaryOfEvents: El día 29 de mayo de 2021 a las 09:50 horas el B/R “Observador” durante un servicio de asistencia a un buque de salida, a la altura del Km 1 del Canal de Acceso Sur al Puerto de Boca del Riachuelo, tuvo un inconveniente en sala de máquinas por el cual debió regresar de emergencia y amarrar en el Puerto de Boca del Riachuelo.

SummaryOfEvents: During the afternoon of 28 May 2021, the general cargo vessel NAZMIYE ANA was carrying out cargo operations, berthed starboard side to the quay at the NOATUM terminal in the port of Castelln. At 20:35 local time, after the port crane had loaded the last container on deck, the vessel began to heel to starboard without stopping, causing the stevedoring company personnel and crew on board to move to the quay or jump into the water. The vessel ended up turning around. Two workers from the stevedoring company were injured and had to be taken to hospital for medical treatment. A crew member and a stevedore were unable to jump onto the quay and were trapped underwater, so a search operation involving the underwater activities group of the GUARDIA CIVIL and SASEMAR was deployed for several days. The body of the crew member was recovered the day after the accident ocurred. The body of the stevedore was recovered twelve days after the accident, once the vessel was removed from the water. The vessel was declared a total lost.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Pollution,Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

Shortly before 02.00 hours (hrs) on the morning of Thursday 14 May 2021 the fishing vessel (FV) Horizon was fishing with four crew onboard, approximately 20 nautical miles (NM) off the Old Head of Kinsale, County Cork, when the Skipper noticed large amounts of smoke coming from the accommodation of the vessel. Despite the crews firefighting efforts, the fire took hold and spread. The Skipper broadcast a MAYDAY distress call by Very High Frequency (VHF) radio and the crew took to a life raft. The crew were recovered from their life raft by the offshore supply ship Pathfinder, but despite efforts to fight the fire by a responding offshore supply ship Maersk Maker, the fishing vessel sank at approximately 07.00 hrs, close to the position where it initially caught fire. There was some sea surface oil pollution reported which appears to have dissipated naturally. Weather and sea conditions at the time were good with light winds and a moderate sea. The crew were subsequently transferred to the Courtmacsherry Lifeboat and brought ashore. There were no injuries suffered by the crew.

On the 4th of May 2021, following the rupture of the towing line in a convoy between the tug Christos XXIV and the laid-up oil tanker Varzuga, an assistance operation involving numerous parties took place under the national maritime emergency response plan ORSEC level 3 (highest level under the Organisation of the Civil Security Response, ORSEC, at sea), activated by the Maritime Prefecture for the Channel and the North Sea. Following this incident at sea, Abeille Libert escorted a convoy formed of Varzuga, towed by Christos XXIV and a tug chartered as an emergency, Mustang, to Le Havre port.

On 1 May 2021, Hong Kong registered bulk carrier “Simon Brother” (the vessel) anchored at the anchorage of the port of Kavieng, the Independent State of Papua New Guinea (PNG) for port formalities and the securing operation of the log cargoes loaded on deck (the securing operation).  At 0830 hours, the crew members of the vessel commenced the securing operation on deck.  At around 0955 hours, an able bodied seaman (AB1) and a deck Fitter (Fitter) noticed the hoisting wire of the No. 1 crane jammed with the hook block (the block).  Without informing the chief officer (the C/O), the AB1 and the Fitter attempted to check the block and its hoisting wire on the top level of the uneven logs.  Suddenly, the block was shifted and rotated during their inspection.  The sudden movement of the block caused the taut wiggle wire to move abruptly, resulting in the AB1 and the Fitter being struck into the sea from the top of the log cargoes.  The Fitter was conscious but the AB1 was observed with his face submerged after falling into the water.  A Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) was performed on the AB1 immediately upon rescued. Unfortunately, at 1258 hours on the same day, the AB1 was declared dead on board by the shore Health Extension Officer (HEO). The investigation had identified the following contributory factors of this accident:  the toolbox talk was not conducted on board before the securing operation in accordance with the requirements of the Shipboard Management System (SMS);  the crew members failed to follow the requirements of the Code of Safe Working Practices for Merchant Seafarers  (the Code) to rig suitable safety nets or temporary fencing while carrying out the securing operation on top of the deck cargoes;  the AB1 and the Fitter had inadequate safety awareness and underestimated the risk of unexpected freeing of the jammed wire during the inspection of the wiggle wire lashing system;  the crew members failed to follow the requirements of the shipboard Cargo Securing Manual (CSM) to carry out the securing operation;  the shipboard training to crew members in the securing operation of the cargoes was ineffective.  
The investigation also revealed that the risk of the securing operation was not covered in the shipboard Risk Assessment Manual (RAM) of the SMS, and the CSM did not update to meet the requirements of the Code of Safe Practice for Ships Carrying Timber Deck Cargoes, 2011 (2011 TDC Code) .

Location: About 1 miles off from the Hanjin Container Terminal on the channel (Fairway No.3)
SummaryOfEvents:
Container vessel, M.V. “SUNNY ROSE” laden with containers of 534 teus (6,824 tons) departed from the Shanghai, China and arrived at Incheon, Korea as a liners schedule, and then berthed alongside Hanjin Container Terminal of Songdo New Port at 1254 hours on 28th April 2021 LMT (UCT+9, hereafter the time is mentioned LMT) and commenced cargo operation from 1356 hours on same date.

In order to depart from Incheon, the vessel has prepared to notify to engine department and checked/tested all navigation equipment as per the required SMS manual at 0100 hours on 29th April and then S.B.E. at 0200 hours on same date. Subsequently the cargo operation was completed at 0230 hours and then pilot came on board at 0254 hours on same date.

The vessel laden with containers of 326 teus (4,657 tons) departed from this port bound for Daesan, Korea with draft, fore 5.70 meters & aft 6.89 meters, at 0300 hours on 29th April 2021. Subsequently the vessel had various heading course 245-260 degrees with speed about 10-11.5 knots in traffic zone (New Port Fairway) by command of pilot until the collision time of about 0310 hours on 29th April and the weather condition at the time is good with visibility over 5 miles.

The vessel identified that a small fishing boat with lights “ILGWANGHO” was approaching to her starboard bow of the vessel “SUNNY ROSE” at about 2-3 miles off & 1 O’clock direction, and the boat proceed to the vessel at speed more than 20 knots and there is CPA of 0.2-0.25 miles off on the vessel’s starboard. The fishing boat’s navigation lights were invisible and only bright lanterns were lit, also the information for the boat was not shown on the vessel’s navigation equipment, such as ECDIS, AIS & etc., so regarding the boat, master of the vessel called/asked to VTS by VHF, but they did not know the boat itself and the vessel could not contact with the fishing boat.

The vessel passed a green buoy light on her starboard and proceed to heading course 260 degrees in the narrow channel (Fairway No.3) by command of pilot with master in attendance, they were paying attention to the fishing boat’s movement and understood the boat would be passed on her starboard. At close distance to the boat, the boat suddenly changed/approached to her starboard and then touched to the vessel’s fore starboard shell plate, then several seconds later, the bright lanterns of the boat were not able to see at the time and expected the boat to be capsized.

At that moment of 0310 hours on 29th April 2021, the vessel steered variously course to hard port / midship / hard starboard by command of pilot and stop engine in order to avoid collision accident and to reduce the extent of the accident.

At about 0313 hours on same date, the vessel reported to the VTS and Incheon Coast Guard the accident of collision which was not occurred oil pollution, subsequently the Coast Guard boat and helicopter came to near on the vessel in order to rescue crew of the fishing boat.

At about 0335 hours on same date, two(2) crew members on board the fishing boat, such as one(1) man & one(1) woman, were rescued by the Coast Guard and they were transported to hospital by ambulance, in which a women died on the way.

InitialEvent: An ordinary seaman was hit by a shackle during securing ship's crane.
SummaryOfEvents:
On 28 April 2021, a fatal accident happened on board a Panama registered container ship “MCC Tokyo” (the vessel) while berthing at the Kwai Tsing Container Terminal, Hong Kong.  An ordinary seaman (OS) was hit by a shackle (the shackle), which was connected to the cargo block of the No.3 ship crane (the cargo block) through a plastic-coated wire loop (the wire) secured with the bulldog grips, falling from a height of about 20 metres above him.
On the day of accident, the cargo operation of the vessel was completed and was being prepared for departure from the Kwai Tsing Container Terminal.  The OS was assigned to assist in securing the No.3 ship crane (the crane) with the lashing ropes onto the lashing bridge before sailing.  After linking the lashing ropes to the cargo block, an able seafarer deck operated the crane to lift the cargo block until the lashing ropes were in tension.  All of a sudden, the wire slid out of the bulldog grips and dropped from a height of about 20 metres.  The shackle connected to the lashing rope with the bulldog grip hit the OS who was working on the lashing bridge underneath the crane.  The OS was evacuated to a local hospital for emergency medical treatment, but he was declared dead on the same day.

On 28 April 2021, the fitter overhauled an air start valve and lapped the spindle and valve seats. Satisfied that the valve was tight, the fitter assembled the valve. In the process, he noticed a piece of cotton entrapped between the spindle and the valve seat. He therefore connected control air to the valve and when the spindle opened, he inserted his thumb in the gap to remove the cotton. It was at this time that the air hoses quick-acting coupling disconnected unexpectedly. The spindle closed on the fitters thumb, causing severe injuries.

SOLASStatus: A SYMPHONY: SOLAS, SEA JUSTICE: Unknown/unspecified
Location: 0Nautical Miles South of Chaolian Island, China
SummaryOfEvents:
The Panama Registered General Cargo Ship SEA JUSTICE (IMO 9309514) collided with the Liberian registered Oil Tanker A SYMPHONY (IMO 9249324) at approximate position Latitude 35o 44.0’ N, Longitude. 120o 58.4’ E at about 0851 LT (all times are expressed in local time) on April 27, 2021. The A SYMPHONY was at anchor in the Qingdao Anchorage, China, and the SEA JUSTICE was underway at about 12 knots in dense fog. 

There were no reported injuries, and no loss of life. There was a serious pollution incident as the number 2 starboard oil tank on the A SYMPHONY was damaged, and about 9000 tons of oil spilled into the sea. 

Both ships were damaged. The A SYMPHONY was ordered to an anchorage position for inspection and repair. After inspection by the local authorities, the A SYMPHONY was allowed to proceed to port to discharge its cargo and for repairs.

This report is based on the information collected immediately after the accident form the operators of the A Symphony and the reports provided by the operators of the SEA JUSTICE and the Local Authorities. 

Due to COVID the Liberian Administration was not able to send an investigator to attend the A SYMPHONY after the collision before the change of ownership in July 27, 2022.

The Liberian Administration did conduct a remote safety inspection on the A SYMPHONY on June 22, 2021 with the assistance of the Master and the Company.  The vessel was found in compliance.

The Liberian Administration has no final investigative report from the operators of the A SYMPHONY and the vessel changed owners and managers on July 27, 2022.

The ship sustained an explosion and subsequently caught fire in a cargo tank while anchored in the Mediterranean Sea W of Jableh, Syrian Arab Republic in LAT. 35 15' 17" N, LONG. 035 55' 18" E PM, on 24 April 2021.
The vessel was conducting STS oil transfer operations with MT 'ARMAN 114' at the time of the incident. Local authorities dispatched a helicopter to the scene. The blaze was extinguished later the same evening. The extent of damage is unknown. The explosion was reportedly due to welding work being carried out in the cargo tank. 2 crew and a local worker died. No pollution was reported. Investigation effected.

On Thursday 22 April 2021, the bulk carrier VAN STAR was sailing up the Seine River bound for Rouen. During the second pilot changeover, the boarding pilot climbed the pilot ladder but before transferring to the accommodation ladder, lost his balance and suddenly let go of it. He fell heavily on the launch which was providing the service of boarding and disembarking the pilots in the port of Rouen. The pilot had been evacuated to Rouen hospital where, suffering from fractures, he underwent surgery followed by a period of rehabilitation before regaining his fitness and resuming his duties.
