SummaryOfEvents: On April 20, 2021, at about 1025 LT, the Able Seafarer (AB) fell into the cargo hold No.3 when the vessel anchored at Kaohsiung No.2 Anchorage position Lat 22-36.1 N Long 120-12.7 E while the crews were assigned to wash down and clean the cargo holds No.2, 4 & 6. The cargo holds No. 1,3,5 & 7 are to be opened for ventilation. The AB was found lying on top of Coal cargo inside cargo hold No.3 unconscious. No witness saw how the AB fell into the cargo hold. The injured AB was airlifted by helicopter to the hospital. Later local agent reported that the injured AB passed away at the hospital.

Location: Onsan Zink terminal in Port of Onsan, Republic of Korea
SummaryOfEvents:
On 14 April 2021, the Hong Kong registered multi-purpose dry cargo ship “Caribbean Harmony” (the vessel) berthed at the Onsan Zink terminal in Port of Onsan, Republic of Korea, and commenced cargo discharge on the same day.
At 0910 hours on 16 April 2021, the charterer’s representative (the representative) boarded the vessel to check the lashing equipment (the equipment) located at the tween deck in the No.1 cargo hold (the hold) for unloading it ashore. The Chief Officer (the C/O) asked the representative to come back later because the crew members were shifting pontoons. However, the representative insisted on taking pictures and checking the equipment immediately. The Third Officer (the 3/O) then accompanied the representative to enter the hold as ordered by the C/O and warned the representative many times not to go near the edge of the tween deck of the hold because of the potential danger of falling but was ignored. At 0915 hours, the representative suddenly fell from the tween deck to the bottom of the hold from the edge of the tween deck opening. The 3/O reported the accident to the C/O immediately and performed Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) on the representative at the spot. Afterwards, the representative was transferred to a local hospital for emergency medical treatment. Unfortunately, the representative was later declared dead on the same day.

SOLASStatus: KHANG ANH 189: SOLAS, SITC KAWASAKI: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
The Ship had a collision with MV 'Sitc Kawasaki' and sank in the south China sea 16 miles SE of Thanh Phu, Ben Tre, Viet Nam in LAT. 09 42' 00" N, LONG. 106 51' 00" E, at 0421 HOURS LT (UTC+7) ON 15 April 2021.
Sustained severe damage and took water before sinking. MV 'Sitc Kawasaki' rescued 10 crew'. The 11th crew member went missing. Viet Nam MRCC despatched 2 rescue vessels, 'SAR 413' & 'SAR 272', to conduct SAR operations. The body of the missing crew member was found in the sunken wreck at 0945 hours LT on 19 April 2021. Investigation effected.

Location: AT EASTERN PART OF BALTIC SEA
SummaryOfEvents:
The MSC SUEZ with IMO no. 8918978 was engaged on a voyage from Antwerp,
Belgium to Saint Petersburg, Russia, covering a total of approximately 1,528
nautical miles.

The voyage was done loaded with containers with a total deadweight of 33,145 mt.
During the voyage four (4) additional sub-contracted welders were onboard to
carry out steel works on a number of ballast tanks.

On the 14th April 2021 two of the welder subcontractors were working inside the
ballast tank no, 6 stbd.

Works were carried out at the top of the tank with a wooden floor erected onto
longitudinal stiffeners between the hull and the double hull.

On the afternoon one of the 14th April 2021 one of the welders left the tank while
the other remained working inside.

One hour later the welder returned to the tank seeing that the second welder was
not inside. Thinking he had gone for dinner the left the tank and proceeded to the
mess room.

During dinner it was advised that one welder never showed up for dinner.

Two (2) of the welders went back to the ballast tank noticing that the missing
welder was lying on the bottom of the tank.

Crew was alerted immediately and Chief Officer was sent to the tank with the
onboard medical team to assist.

Despite all attempts to reanimate the welder, he did not response and based on all
advice given by remote medical assistance he was declared dead.

The body of the welder was lifted and transferred to the ship´s provision chamber
under controlled temperature.

At about 1003 (LT) on 14 April 2021, while one of Celebrity Summits rescue boat was being hoisted back to its nesting position after a dynamic test on the davit winch brake had been completed, the wire snapped. The boat fell into the water from deck no. 5. The vessel was moored alongside at Port Everglades, Florida. The boat was eventually recovered. None of the crew members suffered any injuries, but the rescue boat sustained structural damages to its hull. The MSIU found that although the hoisting button on the winch control had been released, the winch did not stop and eventually, the steel wire failed. Microscopic analysis of the contactor revealed signs of worn and welded contacts tips. The wire ropes condition did not contribute to the accident.

On 12 April 2021, a refresher course in the operation of survival craft and rescue boats was conducted at a training centre in Frihamnen harbour in Stockholm. One of the practise sessions was an exercise in rescuing survivors from the water using a lifeboat. The lifeboat was a totally enclosed model with side hatches that is intended for a maximum of 26 persons. The lifeboat was also approved for use as a rescue boat. During the exercise, the lifeboat started listing heavily and became flooded with water through a side hatch. Three people ended up in the water and the lifeboat had to be abandoned. None of those on board suffered any injuries. During the occurrence, the lifeboat was lightly loaded, with few persons on board in comparison to the capacity of the lifeboat. Some of the basic equipment such as water, provisions etc. was not on board either. All the hatches were open to allow the participants to practise bringing casualties on board out of the water. The forces that arose when the participants in the exercise moved around in the boat resulted in a change in the centre of gravity, which led to the lifeboat starting to list heavily and to the edge of the side hatch ending up under the waterline. The lifeboat complied with applicable stability requirements. Nevertheless, the investigation shows that, under certain conditions, this type of lifeboat has a small stability margin. This means that small forces are able to generate large angles of heel and that, under certain conditions, lifeboats of this type are able to take on water and heel over if the boat is being manoeuvred with open side hatches. This is especially the case when the lifeboat is lightly loaded with few persons on board. It is reasonable to assume that other lifeboats of similar types and sizes may have similar stability properties. The accident was caused by the lifeboats stability properties, which meant that small changes in centre of gravity gave rise to large angles of heel. When those on board moved around in the lifeboat in order to allow the helmsman to be changed, the centre of gravity moved upwards. This led to the boat heeling heavily, taking on water through an open side hatch and heeled over. At system level, the accident was caused by insufficient stability requirements for small, enclosed lifeboats with side openings near the gunwale.

On 25 March 2021, the dry cargo carrier NATALY was at anchor off Landsort, Sweden, waiting for berth and loaded with woodchips. When anchoring, one of the anchor chains had kinked, and the chief mate and the two deck hands, one AB and one OS, had subsequently opened the chain box. The work was prepared through issuing of an enclosed space entry permit. During the work it was noted that a working light was out of order, and one of the two deck hands, the AB, was asked to fetch a replacement. At the same time, the OS was on the forecastle for further preparations. A sound made him go down from the forecastle, and he then saw the hatch down to the forward shaft of the cargo hold being opened. The shaft, that from a ventilation perspective was part of the cargo hold and consequently an enclosed space, was not to be entered until atmosphere was deemed to be safe. All the way down at the bottom, he saw the AB lying and realized that BA set was necessary to assist him. Hence, the OS immediately called for emergency assistance. After a great deal of problems, the AB was brought up on deck through the narrow space while the master called for assistance. Though CPR commenced directly as the AB was on deck, he was still unconscious when the rescue helicopter arrived, and the AB was announced dead upon arrival at the hospital. The post mortem suggests that the deceased was subjected to severe hypoxia and that the cause of death is suffocation as a result of spending time in the shaft. An audit of the vessels SMS that was conducted after the occurrence revealed several nonconformities. Furthermore, one observation was made by the auditor showing that communication between the vessel and the shipping company, Hermann Lohmann Schiffahrtsverwaltung GmbH, regarding safety management issues may be regarded as too limited. This leads to the conclusion that the SMS was not effectively implemented, which in turn constitutes an underlying factor to the occurrence. The direct cause of the accident was that the AB went down into an enclosed space where there was a lack of oxygen. The hatch to the shaft was not cordoned off, which means that a safety barrier was broken. It has however not been possible to establish why the victim went down into the cargo hold shaft. The incomplete implementation of the shipowners and the vessels safety management systems is an underlying factor to the occurence. SummaryOfEvents: On Monday 8 March 2021, the dredging barge LENNART, together with the tug ATLE, was dredging within a restricted area of Stilleryd Harbour outside Karlshamn. That same morning, the ro-ro vessel FINLANDIA SEAWAYS arrived at the harbour. Due to a forthcoming practical exam for fairway-specific pilot exemption certificate, the master manoeuvred the vessel in the fairway towards the dock while the pilot, who had come on board outside of the harbour, took on a supervisory role. Just after the vessel had passed the dredging unit, a turn to port was initiated with the intention of turning the vessel around and then reversing it into its berth further into the harbour. Once the turn had begun, the vessel moved astern and thus got closer to the dredging unit. When the people on the vessels bridge acknowledged the vessels direction of travel and the decreasing distance to the dredging unit, the engine controls were set to full ahead. Just after this, the stern of the vessel collided with the tug ATLE. The collision resulted in extensive damage to ATLE. The occurrence did not result in any personal injuries. The occurrence was caused by inadequate situational awareness among the crew and pilot on board FINLANDIA SEAWAYS. The inadequate situational awareness may be explained to some extent by the manoeuvring controls on the bridge being switched over from the centre console to the bridge wing after the turn to rotate the vessel around had been initiated. In conjunction with the switch-over, the sense of the vessels speed and direction of travel was momentarily lost. The control function, in the form of a lookout in the stern, was activated too late to prevent the collision. Another probable contributing factor is that the master was distracted due to the forthcoming exam and thus lost focus on the vessels movements when she was being turned around.

On Monday the 1 March 2021, three persons worked with diving inspections of the quay facility in Torshamnen in Gothenburg. They worked from the ship VESTA, an eleven-metre-long workboat. At half past nine in the morning, the crew stopped the work to take a lunch break. They intended to moor at the bridge that runs between Torshamnen and Risholmen, a low bridge that has a vertical clearance of about three meters. The boat was slowly manoeuvring towards the bridge and one of the crew members went forward to be ready to moor. The driver engaged reverse gear, but there was no effect, after which he pulled the control further back. VESTA then continued forward in a rapid starboard turn and hit the bridge. The person in the bow did not manage to dodge or get himself to a safe position and got caught between the wheelhouse and the bridge suffering severe fatal injuries. The rescue effort was hampered by the difference in height between the bridge and the boat, but another of the company's boats arrived quickly to the scene of the accident and towed VESTA to the southern end of the bridge where an ambulance could take care of the injured for further transport. The accident was caused by a fatigue induced crack leading to a failure in the stainless-steel wire in the control cable, used for switching between ahead and astern. Ahead remained in place, despite the control lever being pulled towards astern. The control lever then worked in an opposite way in the reverse position and full astern then became full ahead. The short distance to the bridge meant that the driver of the boat did not have time to take any corrective measures before the collision. A prerequisite for the fracture of the metal wire was that the control cable was bent where the flexible casing meets the rigid metal end sleeve, which eventually led to a fatigue fracture due to repeated bending and straightening movements at each shifting. The underlying causes are a lack of ability to inspect the internal condition of the control cable and a lack of specified replacement intervals. It had thus not been possible to determine the condition of the metal wire with less than with destructive testing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

Cooling operations were carried out for a while and the list of the ship was corrected by discharging the water inside.

Location: About 150 miles off the Southeast of Vietnam
SummaryOfEvents:
On 03rd February 2021, vessel M.V Baltic K sailed from the port of Fukuyama, Japan set sails
towards Chittagong, Bangladesh with a cargo of steel coils on board.
On the morning of 10th February at around 10:42 hr (+8 UTC) while the vessel was about 150
miles off the Southeast of Vietnam the Master tried to contact the Chief Engineer, in the engine
room and upon not finding him there asked the 3rd Officer to try to contact and look for him in
various public places but no one reportedly saw him that day. C/E’s locked cabin was opened
by the master key but he was not to be seen there. It was then realized that the Chief Engineer
was missing from his cabin and engine room.
A few minutes later emergency alarm was raised and a public address announcement was made
to search for C/E on board. Ship compliment was put on thorough search on board. Following
this the vessel was turned around on a reciprocal course to head back to the last known position
when C/E was last sighted around midnight of 09th February 2021. In the ship’s crew search on
board, Chief Engineer was not found, soon after the Master informed the Owners about the missing
Chief Engineer.
After informing the ship owners and managers, the vessel began broadcasting an urgent message on
VHF and MF/HF. MRCC Haiphong responded to an urgent call, later around the noon time
Australian Maritime Patrol Aircraft also responded on 10th February. The Australian Maritime
Patrol Aircraft took details of the last sighting of the Chief Engineer and reported that they
would head to the advised location of 23:45hr, 9th February. In the meantime, MRCC Vung
Tau also confirmed the vessel’s report of the Man Overboard.
All this while the vessel was on a reciprocal course with extra lookouts extra posted searching
at sea the missing Chief Engineer. By 14:00hr on 10th Feb, vessel Managers advised to the ship
to resume the voyage to Bangladesh as the SAR would be conducted by the concerned MRCC
and the Australian Aircraft.
By 16:27 hrs, MRCC Singapore had also acknowledged the vessel’s MF/HF call about the Man
Overboard. 10 min later, US Govt. vessel “VSL 14” also exchanged details of the vessel and
joined the SAR.
By 17:35 hrs on 10th Feb, the Australian Maritime Patrol Craft and the US Govt. “VSL 14”
reported no success in finding missing C/E, hence called off the search.

The vessel in transit to Bangladesh stopped and anchored in Singapore on 12th February 2021
for the purpose of bunkering. The Coastguard officials boarded the vessel for an investigation.
Singapore Coastguard interviewed the master & crew, inspected the cabin of the Chief Engineer, and
collected the required information and documents.
The vessel departed from Singapore on the evening of 12th February. She arrived at Chittagong
Roads on 17th February and dropped anchor awaiting cargo discharging orders.
The P&I surveyor boarded the vessel on the 18th of February and carried out an investigation on
behalf of the insurers.
Various attempts were made to establish contact with the wife, the next of kin of the missing Chief
Engineer, but all in vain.
Flag state investigation analysis was carried out on the basis of evidence collected from the ship,
statements and interviews of the crew.
The pointers of the analysis indicate that the missing Chief Engineer after coming out of the engine
room at night ventured outside the accommodation to weather deck area in the dark, where he had
an accidental fall overboard.

On 8 February 2021, there was a sudden death of a seafarer on board MV Eneovai in a position (Lat 03⁰ 27.8’N, Long: 005⁰ 27.8’E) in the vicinity of Agbami Oilfied, Nigeria. 

Prior to the incident, the deceased handed over watch to the Chief Officer at 1200 hours on 8 February, 2021 and proceeded for his lunch, after which he retired to his cabin, expected to resume back at 1745hrs in line with the Company’s six (6) hourly watch keeping policy.

At 1800hrs, when the deceased did not come to take over watch and all efforts to reach him failed, the chief officer decided to send an Able seaman (AB) to his cabin to check on him. The AB called him severally but there was no response, he then radioed the chief officer who sounded emergency signal to alert other crew. All the crew mustered and were informed about the situation. The Chief Officer tried to check the deceased pulse but his body was already stiff.

The Captain placed a call and notified the Agbami Offshore Terminal who immediately sent two medical personnel on board to assess the situation. The medical personnel after examination, confirmed that he has passed on.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: Seafarer was shifting heavy deck pontoons with 3 other crewmembers. The seafarer had to stay in a dedicated safe place until the pontoon was laid off in the right place in the cargo hold. For an unknown reason, the seafarer left his safe place and got hit by the pontoon. A doctor stated that the seafarer deceased immediately as a consequence of the impact of the pontoon.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: On 7 February 2021, the Danish flagged container ship SANTA CLARA was about to berth in the Port of Bremerhaven when an OS fell overboard while rigging the gangway. Several ships in the area searched for the OS, but she was not found. After several hours she was presumed dead.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: Fishing vessel derrick collapsed resulting in one head injury, now deceased, and one back injury. The vessels gear was in the water and have to bring it back on aboard before they can go back to port.

At approximately 14.05 hours (hrs) on the afternoon of 3 February 2021, a serious marine casualty occurred on the fishing vessel (FV) Marliona while alongside Greencastle Harbour, Co Donegal. During a repair process the Skippers left arm became trapped by a trawl door causing severe damage to his arm. First aid was administered by another crewmember and the bleeding was stopped. The ambulance was called and arrived at 14.30 hrs, and the Casualty was transferred to the nearest hospital where he was treated for his injuries. The hospital treated the Casualty and managed to save his arm. He was released the same day but continued to receive treatment and only returned to work in May 2021.

VALARIS DS-4, which was in lay-up, was blown off the Hunterston Jetty and suffered a loss of moorings during a period of storm force winds on the evening of 2 February 2022. The drill ship's anchor had previously been set as part of the its mooring arrangements. VALARIS DS-4 drifted to the southwest until the anchor held and stopped the vessel was drifting when it was approximately halfway across the channel. There were no injuries or pollution. The only damage was that all of the drill ship's mooring lines parted. There was no damage to port infrastructure.

SOLASStatus: TEAM BELEUZI: Unknown/unspecified, TOPAZ ENERGY: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
On 31st January, 2021,  at about 2355hrs, a fatal man overboard incident occurred onboard a Nigerian flagged Offshore Supply Vessel (OSV) “Topaz Energy” while she was “double banked” with a sister vessel “Team Beleuzi” 

In a VHF communication between the two vessels at about 1800hrs, the chief Officer and 2nd Officer onboard Team Beleuzi realized that the Second Officer of Topaz Energy was their old friend and they decided to board Topaz Energy. Onboard the ship, the crew stayed until about 2353hrs when they decided to cross back to their ship. The Second Officer of Topaz Energy also decided to accompany them.

The chief Officer of team Beleuzi approached the ship side and managed to cross back to his ship, unfortunately, while the Second Officer of Topaz Energy was trying to cross, he loosed his grip and fell overboard. He was rescued few minutes later and conveyed to the hospital where he was pronounced dead.

SOLASStatus: FPSO CIDADE DE MANGARATIBA - MV 24: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
On January 31 st , 2021, at 3:45 pm, the professional, man 01, non-crew, suffered a
fall from about 18m high, while performing work at height with rope access inside the 7S
cargo tank, preparing the site for a subsequent work to measure the thickness of the
plate of the vessel “FPSO CIDADE DE MANGARATIBA MV24”, with a Bahamas flag,
which was in production in the Santos Basin.

At 0530 hours on 29 January 2021, a Hong Kong registered bulk carrier “Qing Ping Shan” (the vessel) dropped anchor at Astoria anchorage in the Columbia River, USA, awaiting berthing instruction for loading wheat in bulk.
In the afternoon of 30 January 2021, the main engine of the vessel was tested under engine control room (ECR) control mode after obtaining the agreement with the Chief Engineer (C/E) and approval from the duty officer on the bridge. After the completion of the test at about 1451 hours, the First Engineer (1/E) made a telephone call to the Fitter’s cabin informing him to arrange the cleaning of the engine room as instructed by the C/E, but nobody answered. The 1/E then searched the engine room for the Fitter. At about 1500 hours, the Fitter was found seriously injured, lying unconsciously on the engine room (E/R) tank top between the main engine flywheel and the main lubrication oil pump with a paint bucket and a roller at his side. The Fitter was sent ashore for emergency medical treatment, but unfortunately, the shore doctor declared him dead at 1601 hours on the same day.

Giulia I departed from the port of Norfolk, USA, bound for Bizerte, Tunisia on 26 January 2021. During the voyage, the vessel experienced inclement weather and the voyage plan was progressively amended, based on the advice received from a weather routeing service. On 29 January 2021, the eductor was started to pump out the water from the forecastle store, which was found flooded by the crew members. On the next day, five deck crew members, including the deck cadet, were instructed to extract the remaining water from the forecastle store and chain lockers, using portable pumps, dry up the store, cover the spurling pipes on the forecastle deck, and arrange and secure all equipment within the store. The vessels course was altered to minimize the rolling and pitching and thus, facilitate the safety of the deck ratings. Whilst the crew members were covering the spurling pipes, a large wave washed over the forecastle deck. All the crew members were swept across the forecastle. Injured crew members were helped back to the accommodation. In the meantime, the vessel diverted towards the port of Halifax, Canada. Eventually, one of the injured crew members succumbed to his injuries whilst the vessel was still en route. The safety investigation concluded that there was a sense of urgency to pump out the accumulated water and take immediate action to prevent further flooding. Moreover, the weather conditions limited the extent of the course alteration.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: Mar Argentino, Golfo San Matías, Provincia de Río Negro
SummaryOfEvents: El 27 de enero aproximadamente a las 00:30 horas, durante la navegación a zona de pesca y con condiciones meteorológicas favorables, se produjo una vía de agua por debajo de la línea de flotación. La embarcación se hundió y toda la tripulación fue rescatada por otro buque pesquero.

On January 26 ,2021, during commissioning of the ps main engine after a major overhaul in dry-dock, smoke and flames were visible on the engine outlet to the exhaust pipe, inside the engine room. The engine room had been evacuated and all doors were closed, vents were shut off. NOVEC had not been activated. After a short moment, no more flames were visible. Probably a small oil leak of one of the cilinders caused the fire. No damage was noted. MAN service engineers were on board.

Location: 50 NM Southeast of SW Pass Mississippi River
SummaryOfEvents:
MODU “WEST NEPTUNE” whilst operating within the US EEZ, Gulf of Mexico, approximately 50 NM Southeast of Southwest Pass Mississippi River, reported a death on  board. The deceased was a third-party contractor employed by Allrig Inc. serving on board the subject vessel for the purpose of inspecting for loose or damaged gear meant for lifting, securing, and rigging operations.  It is a customary inspection said to be carried out quarterly after completion of changing the color codes for rigging and lifting equipment on board the vessel.  

Allrig Inc sent 2 individuals, Mr. Robert Philliskirk and Mr. Thiago Ribeiro, who were on board since 20 January 2021 for inspecting & checking loose lifting gears on board the subject vessel.   

On 24 January 2021 while completion work was in progress a fatal mishap occurred on board at 1330 hours while Allrig personnel were checking and inspecting loose lifting gear in the riser bay. One Allrig person, Mr. Robert Philliskirk, was pinned in between falling steel plates and the vessel’s steel structure and was killed. 
Mr. Ribeiro, the other employee of Allrig Inc, immediately called for help, but by the time the vessel’s medic arrived, the mishap victim, Mr. Philliskirk, had already expired and was declared dead at 1337 hours.
The deceased’s mortal remains were later removed from the scene at about 1806 hours after the USCG gave permission for the body to be removed.

The drilling and rig operations were suspended for investigation from 24 Jan later resumed on 26 January evening after all enquiries of local authorities were completed.

Location: Zona Económica Exclusiva a 186 millas náuticas de Bahía Camarones. Argentina
SummaryOfEvents:
El buque pesquero Nanina, zarpó de puerto Mar del Plata el día 19 de enero a las 18:05 horas rumbo a zona de pesca de calamar.
El día 24 de enero a las 09:55 horas se inició un incendio en sala de máquinas mientras el buque se encontraba en zona de pesca.
El fuego fue extinguido por la tripulación utilizando los dispositivos de lucha contra incendio abordo, solo se reportaron daños materiales sin víctimas fatales.
A las 12:05 horas el buque reinició navegación por sus propios medios hacia su puerto de asiento amarrando el día 26 de enero a las 11:50 horas en el puerto de Mar del Plata.

On 22 January 2021 at 15:55 hours Ships Time (ST) (UTC+1), while the container ship NORDIC HAMBURG was navigating in the Baltic Sea en route from Antwerp (Belgium) to Saint Petersburg (Russian Federation), loaded with 9415 MT containerized cargo and 13 crew members on board, its Ukrainian Chief Engineer (C/E), was reported missing.He was last seen at 14:25 hours ST, in the Engine Control Room (ECR). Crew searched the entire vessel with negative results. The MRCC-Tallinn (Estonia) was informed and conducted search and rescue (SAR) operation. Vessel turned on a reciprocal course and carried out SAR operation, under the command of the MRCC-Tallinn. Other vessels in the vicinity participated in the SAR operation. The C/E was not found. At the time when the MRCC-Tallinn ceased the SAR operation, the maximum survival time was exceeded since long.

The ship was reported missing and presumed sank in the Caribbean Sea, approximately 70 miles NW of Cartagena, Colombia on 21 January 2021. A distress signal was received from the ship's EPIRB and an SAR operation was effected by the Colombian Navy and Air Force ships and aircrafts. All 10 crew remained missing. The EPIRB and some items of cargo were recovered from the area and subsequently some of the ship documents were washed ashore.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
Discharge by oil from MV QUEBEC into 
the sea at Graciosa Bay, Temotu Province, Solomon Islands.
ClassificationSociety1: Polski Rejestr Statkow (Polish Register of Shipping) (PRS)

SummaryOfEvents: During ocean passage within the Great Barrier Reef, the cargo vessel 'Trinity Bay' ran aground on Harrington Shoal, within the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, North Queensland, Australia. The crew anchored the vessel while waiting to attempt to refloat on the following high tide. The investigation is continuing.

At about 1530 hours on 18 January 2021, a fatal accident happened on board the Hong Kong registered bulk carrier “Bao Run” (the vessel) at sea at approximate position 17o29.3’N 058o07.0’E, during her voyage from Bin Qasim, Pakistan to King Abdullah, Saudi Arabia for loading clinker cargo. 
In the accident, the Second Engineer (the 2/E) without wearing a safety belt fell from the Permanent Means of Access (PMA) platform at the height of about 15 metres onto the tank top while he was carrying out cargo hold cleaning operation in the No.4 cargo hold (the cargo hold). 
The Wiper saw the 2/E lying on the bottom of the cargo hold adjacent to the bilge well having a serious head injury with bleeding.  Subsequently, the 2/E was lifted out from the cargo hold with a stretcher and transferred to the outside of the port accommodation area for first aid treatment.  The Master altered the vessel’s course to the Salalah port about 251 nautical miles away to evacuate the 2/E for medical treatment ashore.  However, the 2/E did not show any vital signs at about 1710 hours on the same day and the vessel resumed her voyage later

While en route from Poti Port/Georgia to Burgas, Bulgaria, the vessel was in anchor in Bartin anchorage due to bad weather. The vessel broke into two and sank completely. Liferafts were used for the crew to abandon the vessel.

Turkish Coast Guard boat carried SAR operation and rescue three crew at first.    After several attempts of SAR including the Turkish Coast Guard helicopter and diving team and the Turkish Navy frigate six of the crew members were rescued safely, unfortunately, the crew members were found dead and another five are missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
The NAVIOS SOL with IMO no. 9545170 was engaged on a voyage from Saldanha Bay, South Africa to Eregli, Turkey, covering a total of approximately 7,140 nautical miles.
The vessel originally sailed from the Port Saldanha Bay, South Africa on the 24th December 2020 with instructions to proceed to the Port of Eregli, Turkey.

	On the morning of 16th January 2021 the fitter was scheduled to carry out a job on a hose drain located in the deck head of the engine workshop.

	The Fitter and the 3rd Engineer commenced all preparations for the job which included fitting and climbing a vertical ladder to work aloft approximately five (5) to six (6) meters above the workshop floor. 

	While the 3rd Engineer was preparing some tools away from the ladder, a large slam noise was heard and fitter laid unconscious and bleeding from his head.

        At that time the vessel was in position 36º 028 N – 022º 44.4 E 

        Several attempts were immediately made to apply first aid and cardiopulmonary resuscitation.

	The vessel diverted to Vatika Bay in the South of Greece for immediate evacuation by helicopter. 

	The fitter was declared dead on arrival to hospital.  

	This report will try to analyse the different contributing factors leading to this fatality as well as listing possible remedial actions to prevent similar accidents.

	All times given in this report are ship´s times UTC.
The ship was exposed to sudden and short-termed violent rolling. During the heavy rolling, 689 containers were lost over board and 258 were damaged.

On 10 January 2021, the Hong Kong registered general cargo ship “Ocean Gold” (the vessel) berthed at Kwangyang, South Korea to discharge coal cargo.
At about 1510 hours on 15 January 2021, the Ordinary Seaman (the OS) reported to the Second Officer (the 2/O) that the cargo of the No.1 cargo hold (the hold) was completely discharged.  The 2/O instructed the duty Able Bodied Seaman (the AB) with the OS to close the hold’s hatch cover.     At about 1515 hours, the AB found the OS lying on the bottom of the hold and realized that the OS could have fallen onto the bottom of the hold from the hatch coaming at a height of 13.28 metres.  He reported the incident to the 2/O via portable radio for help.  A shipboard rescue team was immediately organised when the Chief Officer (the C/O) received the report.  The OS was transferred to shore by the ship crane with a stretcher. He was then conveyed to a local hospital for first-aid treatment. Unfortunately, the OS was later declared dead on the same day.

At 1100 the crew were evacuated, the agent of the boat was informed and the necessary procedure was done

On January 14, 2021, at the end of the afternoon, fishing finishing, the Captain of the trawler BREIZ informed MRCC Jobourg that vessel has a steering gear breakdown in front of Port-en-Bessin Harbour. With a strong wind pushing her towards the coast, the vessel anchored on one of its dredges waiting for assistance. Due to the weather conditions, which made access to Port-en-Bessin difficult, the Ouistreham rescueboat, SNS 091 SAINTE ANNE DES FLOTS, was engaged for a towing operation. The SNS 091 SAINTE ANNE DES FLOTS joined the BREIZ in the evening. By night, during the towing operation, the BREIZ capsized and sank suddenly.

InitialEvent: Hit by Wave at Forecastle deck during heavy weather
SummaryOfEvents:
On January 12, 2021 at about 0850 LT, while en route from Krishnapatnam, India to Xia Men, China to discharge granite, vessel at South China Sea position Lat 08-16 N Long 108-53 E, the Chief Officer (C/O) who went to Forecastle to check the condition of mooring rope, anchor and windless due to adverse weather, with Bosun and Able Seafarer (AB) were hit by the wave. The C/O had injured very seriously. The vessel diverted to Vung Tau, Vietnam for medical assistance as per company instruction. On January 13, 2021 at 0830 vessel arrived Vung Tau anchorage, unfortunately the doctor confirmed that C/O deceased at 0930 LT.
During the incident gale force warning had been issued the weather was recorded as Wind=NEx8, Swell=NEx7, Visibility= good, and Temperature= 25℃.

Fabio Duo was engaged in the strengthening and lengthening of the outer breakwater of Santa Margherita Ligure Harbour. The vessels crane was being used to transfer boulders from the cargo hold and place them in position at the breakwater. The master, who was on duty at the time, walked forward to check on some maintenance, which the crew had carried out earlier. On his way back to the accommodation, he decided to check on the status of the cargo hold. While checking on the cargo, the crane turned towards the breakwater and trapped the master in between the body of the crane and the hatch coaming. Consequently, the master sustained serious injuries to his torso.

Ohio was underway to a bunkering area, transporting a surveyor to a vessel anchored in that area. On noticing lights of a fish farm flashing on Ohios port bow, the lookout advised the coxswain to alter the boats course to port to avoid the fish farm. Reportedly, the coxswain experienced difficulty in looking through the boats windscreen, due to salt hindering his visibility. Sometime after the alteration of course to port was executed, Ohio allided with and entered one of the fish cages of the fish farm. The boat was subsequently pulled out of the fish cage, some hours later, and towed towards Valletta. Neither did any injuries nor pollution result from this accident, however, the pilot boat sustained damages to both her rudders and propellers, rendering her unable to maneuver, along with minor damages to her keel. The fish cage, which was empty at the time of the accident, sustained material damages.

On 7 January 2021 the ro-ro vessel BENTAGO EXPRESS had made the voyage between Santa Cruz de Tenerife and Agaete (Gran Canaria). During the manoeuvre to enter the port of Las Nieves in Agaete, with bad weather, the vessel was unable to give the mooring lines. A strong gust of wind blew the ship to port, driving her into the shallows of Marina Norte, where she ran aground. After several unsuccessful attempts to get out of the grounding by their own means, the crew notified the rescue services about the emergency. Due to the bad weather it was not possible to evacuate the passengers and crew until the following day. Six days later the vessel was pulled out from the rocks and moored at the Las Nieves dock A few days later she was transferred to a repair yard in Las Palmas de Gran Canaria.

On 06-1-2021 whilst engaged in fishery the vessel suffered a massive flooding in the engine room. The crew requested assistance to other fishing vessel in the vicinity. Crewmember was injured during shifting vessels.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship
